title: International Diabetes Federation-Diabetes and Ramadan Alliance (IDF-DAR) Fasting Risk Assessment
description: Stratifies risk of fasting during Ramadan in diabetic patients using validated clinical parameters. The IDF-DAR tool provides evidence-based guidance for healthcare providers and patients to make informed decisions about the safety of fasting during Ramadan based on diabetes type, glycemic control, complications, and other risk factors.

parameters.name: diabetes_type
parameters.description: Type of diabetes mellitus. Type 1 diabetes carries higher baseline fasting risk due to insulin dependence and greater glycemic variability

parameters.name: years_since_diagnosis
parameters.description: Duration of diabetes diagnosis. Longer duration associated with increased risk of complications and glucose variability

parameters.name: hypoglycemia_frequency
parameters.description: Frequency and severity of hypoglycemic episodes. Recent severe hypoglycemia or hypoglycemia unawareness significantly increases fasting risk

parameters.name: hba1c_level
parameters.description: Glycemic control measured by HbA1c. Poor control (>9%) indicates higher risk of acute complications during fasting

parameters.name: treatment_type
parameters.description: Current diabetes treatment regimen. Insulin therapy and certain sulfonylureas increase hypoglycemia risk during fasting

parameters.name: self_monitoring_frequency
parameters.description: Blood glucose self-monitoring frequency. Regular monitoring enables safer fasting through early detection of glucose abnormalities

parameters.name: acute_complications
parameters.description: History of acute diabetic complications including diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) or hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS) within the past 3 months

parameters.name: macrovascular_disease
parameters.description: Presence of macrovascular complications including coronary artery disease, cerebrovascular disease, or peripheral arterial disease

parameters.name: renal_complications
parameters.description: Diabetic nephropathy or chronic kidney disease stage 4-5 (eGFR <30 mL/min/1.73mÂ²)

parameters.name: pregnancy_status
parameters.description: Pregnancy or breastfeeding status. Pregnant and breastfeeding women with diabetes are generally advised against fasting

parameters.name: frailty_cognitive_function
parameters.description: Frailty or cognitive impairment that may impair ability to recognize or respond to hypoglycemia symptoms

parameters.name: physical_labor
parameters.description: Occupation involving intense physical labor or activity that increases metabolic demands and hypoglycemia risk during fasting

parameters.name: previous_ramadan_experience
parameters.description: Experience with previous Ramadan fasting. Prior successful fasting may indicate better tolerance and risk management

parameters.name: fasting_hours
parameters.description: Duration of daily fasting hours based on geographic location and season. Longer fasting periods increase dehydration and hypoglycemia risk

result.name: risk_score
result.description: IDF-DAR fasting risk score with risk category classification

ranges.interpretation: Low risk for complications during Ramadan fasting. Patient can likely fast safely with appropriate education and monitoring. Recommend pre-Ramadan counseling on meal timing, glucose monitoring, and recognition of hypoglycemia symptoms. Consider adjusting medication timing but major therapy changes usually not required. Monitor for breakthrough hypoglycemia and maintain regular follow-up.

Moderate risk for complications during Ramadan fasting. Requires careful evaluation and enhanced monitoring. Consider medication adjustments, intensified glucose monitoring, and structured diabetes education. Patients should have clear action plans for hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia. Close supervision by healthcare team recommended. May fast with medical supervision if patient strongly desires.

High risk for serious complications during Ramadan fasting. Generally advised against fasting due to significant risk of hypoglycemia, hyperglycemia, diabetic ketoacidosis, or other acute complications. If patient insists on fasting despite medical advice, requires intensive monitoring, immediate access to medical care, and detailed emergency action plans. Consider alternative spiritual practices and emphasize that health preservation is a religious priority.

references: Hassanein M, Sahay BK, Hafidh K, Djaballah K, Li H, Rahim MA, et al. Diabetes and Ramadan: Practical guidelines 2021. Diabetes Res Clin Pract. 2022 Mar;185:109185. doi: 10.1016/j.diabres.2021.109185.

Ibrahim M, Al Magd MA, Annabi FA, Assaad-Khalil S, Ba-Essa EM, Fahdil I, et al. Recommendations for management of diabetes during Ramadan: update 2020, applying evidence from a decade of research. BMJ Open Diabetes Res Care. 2020 May;8(1):e001248. doi: 10.1136/bmjdrc-2020-001248.

Alam F, Oubari S, Ahmad J, Eba-Alkhayri A, Almadani A, Babineaux S, et al. Validity of the International Diabetes Federation risk stratification score of Ramadan fasting in individuals with diabetes mellitus. Saudi Med J. 2024 Jan;45(1):86-92. doi: 10.15537/smj.2024.45.1.20230497.
formula: Risk Score = Diabetes Type + Years Since Diagnosis + Hypoglycemia Score + HbA1c Score + Treatment Score + Monitoring Score + Complication Scores + Social Factors
notes: The IDF-DAR tool was developed through international consensus and validated across multiple populations
Fasting during Ramadan is a personal decision that should involve patient preference and medical guidance
Patients in all risk categories should receive pre-Ramadan education on glucose monitoring and symptom recognition
Medication timing adjustments may be necessary regardless of risk category
Emergency action plans should be established for all patients who choose to fast
Regular medical follow-up is essential during Ramadan fasting period
